instruction: Can spectroscopic methods be used in the related study to assess the impacts of oil spills on coastal vegetation and wetland, monitor the recovery pattern of polluted vegetation and wetland, and quantify the area extent of oil pollution on coastal vegetation and wetland using remote sensing imagery and machine learning models?

These indices, such as the Chlorophyll Vegetation Index, Modified Difference Water Index, Normalized Difference Vegetation Index, and Green Chlorophyll Index, are sensitive to changes in vegetation health and can be used to assess the impact of oil spills and monitor recovery patterns. Machine learning models, specifically Support Vector Machine (SVM) and Random Forest (RF), are employed to classify and quantify the polluted and non-polluted vegetation and wetlands based on the spectral information. The accuracy assessments of these models confirm their effectiveness in identifying and quantifying the area extent of oil pollution on coastal vegetation and wetland. Therefore, spectroscopic methods, in combination with remote sensing imagery and machine learning models, are essential tools in this study for assessing oil spill impacts and monitoring recovery patterns.
